training_organizations.name: Maine Child Welfare Training Institute (USM)
training_organizations.description: A partnership between Maine’s Office of Child and Family Services and the University of Southern Maine that trains child welfare caseworkers. This institute develops curriculum and conducts training for new OCFS staff on Maine’s policies and practice model, and offers advanced training (e.g. assessment of substance-affected infants, engaging fathers) to improve workforce competence.

training_organizations.name: Adoptive & Foster Families of Maine (AFFM)
training_organizations.description: A nonprofit organization that contracts with Maine’s OCFS to support and train resource families:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}. AFFM provides pre-service training to prospective foster/adoptive parents, peer support and mentoring for licensed families, and assistance with placements – bolstering Maine’s ability to recruit and retain quality foster homes for children in care.

training_organizations.name: Public Consulting Group (PCG)
training_organizations.description: A consulting firm hired by Maine to evaluate and improve the child welfare system. PCG conducted a comprehensive assessment of Maine’s CPS operations in recent years and provided recommendations for system reforms:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}. For example, PCG’s evaluation identified high caseloads and training needs, recommending that Maine align caseworker training with national best practices and develop better workload management strategies:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}.

data.award_title: National Tribal Child Welfare Center for Innovation and Advancement

policies.TribalFoster: No, Tribes within state do not provide foster care
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Other: Emotional maltreatment includes exposure to domestic violence
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes non-organic failure to thrive
policies.DefPerp_OtherSpecify: Any person, regardless of whether or not the person is responsible for the child
policies.NearFatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.TribalScreen_Specify: The Passamaquoddy Tribe; The Penobscot Nation; The Houlton Band of Maliseets; The Mi'kmaq Nation
policies.Reporter_OtherSpecify: A homemaker; A state or municipal fire inspector; A municipal code enforcement official; A chair of a professional licensing board that has jurisdiction over mandated reporters; Humane agent employed by the Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry; Family or domestic violence victim advocates; Any person who has assumed full, intermittent or occasional responsibility for the care or custody of the child, regardless of whether the person receives compensation
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: Gather contact and identifying information about relatives; Identification of any pets in the home; Complete UNCOPE questionnaire to identify substance abuse; Assessment of strengths and needs of the family related to child safety; Create Plan of Safe Care for report including Drug Affected Baby (DAB)
policies.ScreenReq_OtherSpecify: Determination of whether family has a tribal affiliation; Determine cultural and ethnic factors; Perform resource review; Check related databases including ACES, Bureau of Motor Vehicles, criminal history, and sex offender registry
policies.InvestQual_OtherSpecify: Conditional or full licensure at the LSW level as issued by the Maine State Board of Social Work Licensure
policies.ReportInfo_OtherSpecify: Information about known risk factors (such as, domestic violence, substance use, mental health issues, medical conditions, etc.)
policies.AntiDiscrim_OtherSpecify: Association; Previous assertion of a claim or right; Whistleblower activity
policies.InvestStaff_OtherSpecify: Child interviews for allegations of child sexual abuse must be completed at the Child Advocacy Center where professionals from law enforcement, child protection, prosecution, mental health, medical, and advocacy agencies collaborate
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: For child sex trafficking, the perpetrator may be any person regardless of whether or not the person is responsible for the child. For other types of maltreatment, the perpetrator is defined as a person responsible for the child.
policies.ScreenerQual_OtherSpecify: Conditional or full licensure at the Licensed Social Worker (LSW) level as issued by the Maine State Board of Social Work Licensure
policies.CaseManagerQual_OtherSpecify: Conditional or full licensure at the LSW level as issued by the Maine State Board of Social Work Licensure
policies.InvestReq_OtherCases_Specify: Plan of Safe Care is required for reports of a Drug Affected Baby only; All other listed activities are required for all cases
policies.ReporterPenalty_OtherSpecify: A homemaker; A state or municipal fire inspector; A municipal code enforcement official; A chair of a professional licensing board that has jurisdiction over mandated reporters; Humane agent employed by the Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry; Family or domestic violence victim advocates; Any person who has assumed full, intermittent or occasional responsibility for the care or custody of the child, regardless of whether the person receives compensation
policies.ScreenerQual_TrainingSpecify: Structured Decision Making (SDM) training; Foundations training for new workers
policies.ReporterTraining_OtherSpecify: A homemaker; A state or municipal fire inspector; A municipal code enforcement official; A chair of a professional licensing board that has jurisdiction over mandated reporters; Humane agent employed by the Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry; Family or domestic violence victim advocates; Any person who has assumed full, intermittent or occasional responsibility for the care or custody of the child, regardless of whether the person receives compensation
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: Physical abuse; Neglect; Physical symptomology; Sexual abuse
policies.NearFatalities_SpecificSpecify: Serious injuries include an injury resulting from Shaken Baby Syndrome, any injury to a child under 6 months of age, abusive head trauma, skull fracture, inflicted head injury, subdural hematoma, multiple fractures, severe beating resulting in extensive contusions or welts, any injury resulting from Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy, drowning, non-organic failure to thrive, and other significant injuries which may have been inflicted by a person responsible for the child and/or are not consistent with the explanation offered
